article: The Main Differences (& Similarities) Between Methodists & Baptists
intro: Ever wondered what the differences between the Methodist and Baptist denominations are? Both are considered branches of the Christian tree but have their own unique worship and organizational practices. The main difference is that Baptists only practice immersion baptism for adults and youths who can declare their faith, while Methodists do sprinkling, pouring, and immersion baptisms for infants, adults, and youths. Keep reading for the differences, similarities, core beliefs, and notable people of each church.

points.name: Main Differences Between Methodists and Baptists

steps.title: Baptists believe salvation is only through faith and Methodists don’t.
steps.subtitle: Baptists believe that you can be saved through faith in God’s grace and the Lord and Savior Jesus Christ. Methodists, on the other hand, believe that salvation is a lifelong process. Baptism, good works, church membership, and communion are all part of that process.
sub-points: Methodists don’t believe that God predestines some people to salvation and others to condemnation. Baptists tend to not take a stance on predestination.
Baptists believe that baptism, church membership, communion, and good works are important, but are not necessary for salvation.

steps.title: Both denominations came from the Protestant Reformation.
steps.subtitle: The Protestant Reformation was a religious revolution that happened in the 16th century, when the Church of England broke away from the Catholic church, creating other Christian branches in the process.
sub-points: The Baptist church was strongly inspired by Calvinism, which was created by John Calvin, a leading Protestant reformer.
The founders of Methodism shared the spirit of Protestant reformers, and some of the Methodist movement came out of Calvinistic ideals.

points.name: Which came first, Methodists or Baptists?

steps.title: The Baptist movement probably started before Methodism.
steps.subtitle: Most historians think that the first Baptist congregation appeared in 1609 in Holland, where the Church of England minister, John Smyth, scandalously baptized himself and other church members. Church of England minister John Wesley created Methodist clubs starting in 1839.
sub-points: Methodism was typically more popular in urban areas, while Baptism was most popular in the rural American South.

points.name: Can Methodists attend Baptist church, and vice versa?
What are the 3 core beliefs of the Baptist church?

steps.title: Baptist churches emphasize the Bible, true believers, and independence.
steps.subtitle: Baptism founder John Smyth and reformer Thomas Helwys joined a group of separatists in England in 1606 and came up with the 3 core beliefs that later shaped the Baptist church.
sub-points: The Bible, not church tradition, was the guide for faith and practice.
The church should only be made up of believers, not everyone who was born in the local parish.
The church should be governed by believers, not by hierarchical figures like bishops.

points.name: What are the “4 alls” of the Methodist church?

steps.title: Methodists believe that all can and need to be saved completely.
steps.subtitle: Methodists tend to follow the Protestant branch of the Christian tree, and their core beliefs align with Orthodox Christianity. These 4 core beliefs are sometimes known as the “4 alls.”
sub-points: All need to be saved (doctrine of original sin).
All can be saved (Universal Salvation).
All can know they are saved (Assurance).
All can be saved completely (Christian perfection).

steps.title: Famous Methodists include Richard Allen and Albert Outler.
steps.subtitle: John Wesley, the founder of Methodism, was a missionary in the American colonies in the 1700s. Methodism spread rapidly in America and broke away from the Church of England in 1797, which is why most of these famous Methodists are from the U.S.
sub-points: John and Charles Wesley, English Methodist movement leaders.
Richard Allen, American freedman and Methodist preacher.
E. Stanley Jones, American Methodist theologian and missionary in India.
Albert Outler, American Methodist historian, theologian, and pastor.
Thomas Welch, British-American Methodist minister and creator of Welch’s grape juice.
Thomas C. Oden, American Methodist theologian and author.
Richard B. Hays, American New Testament scholar, professor, and Methodist minister.
